item.title: I Egoism
item.description: Lecture notes on psychological egoism.

item.title: II Egoism: Empirical and Quasi-Empirical Issues
item.description: Lecture notes on psychological egoism, arguments from unconscious motives, arguments from evolutionary biology, and empirical work.

item.title: III Belief/Desire Psychology & The Humean Theory of Motivation
item.description: III Belief/Desire Psychology & The Humean Theory of Motivation Lecture notes on belief/desire psychology and the Humean theory of motivation.

item.title: IV Bratman on Intention
item.description: Lecture notes on intention, Michael Bratman, the functional benefits of intention, desires, believes, action, and the Humean theory of motivation.

item.title: IX Strength of Will: Normative Issues
item.description: lecture notes on strength of will, normative issues, Ainslie’s conditionals, Kavka’s toxin puzzle, two other puzzle cases, Bratman’s troublemaking principles, two putative solutions, Bratman’s solution, and the case of Yuri.

item.title: V Velleman on Intention
item.description: Lecture notes on intention as belief, motivation by desire, Langton’s worries, and keeping a belief requirement without equating intention with belief.

item.title: VI Akrasia
item.description: Lecture notes on akrasia, weakness of will, Socrates’s position, Davidson’s presentation on the problem, and Davidson’s solution.

item.title: VII Akrasia & Desire
item.description: Lecture notes on akrasia and desire, Watson’s criticisms of Davidson, Humberstone’s distinctions, and akrasia and weakness of will.

item.title: VIII Strength of Will: Descriptive Issues
item.description: Lecture notes on strength of will, Ainslie’s eight marks of the will, weakness of will, the enduring self, worries, ego depletion, Mischel’s findings, and separate neural systems.

item.title: X Strength of Will: More Normative Issues
item.description: Lecture notes on two versions of the linking principle and a principle linking them, a counterexample to strong link, the rationality of strong resolution, explaining what is right about the no-regret consition, and paradoxes.

item.title: XI Addiction I
item.description: Lecture notes on addiction, no choice models, and rational choice models.

item.title: XII Addiction II
item.description: Lecture notes on irrational choice models, and models for addiction from Kent C. Barridge, George Ainslie, and Gary Watson.

item.title: XIII Free Will I
item.description: Lecture notes on the problems, phenomenology, and responsibility of free will, a first argument for compatibilism: Hobbes’ solution, and Frankfurt’s account of freedom.

item.title: XIV Free Will II
item.description: Lecture notes on free will, Frankfurt on alternative possibilities, Locke, the flicker strategy, and dispositions.

item.title: XIX Identification
item.description: Lecture notes on identification, Frankfurt, Harry G., wholeheartedness, and T. M. Scanlon.

item.title: XV Free Will III: Strawsonshe
item.description: Lecture notes on free will, responsibility, and the limits of evil.

item.title: XVI Free Will IV: Libertarianism
item.description: Lecture notes on Robert Kane’s libertarianism.

item.title: XVII Free Will V: Choice
item.description: Lecture notes on aspects of free will, the phenomenology of freedom, standard compatibilist accounts, the need for choice, and judgement.

item.title: XVIII Free Will VI: Empirical Work
item.description: Lecture notes on free will, Daniel M. Wegner, and Benjamin Libet.

item.title: XX Self-Determination Theory
item.description: Lecture notes on self-determination theory, fundamental motivations, and the work of Edward Deci and Richard Ryan.

item.title: XXI Self-Deception
item.description: Lecture notes on empirical findings on self-deception, deception by others, the divided self, and Alfred R. Mele on self-deception.

item.title: XXII The Metaethical Implications of Empirical Work
item.description: Lecture notes on meta-ethics, judgments and motivation, a mathematical model for ethics, a linguistic model for ethics, the Protagorean position, and empirical work.

item.title: XXIII Moral Judgement and Motivation
item.description: Lecture notes on moral judgement and motivation, the moral/conventional distinction, and Nichols’ sentimental rules account.

item.title: XXIV Autism and Sociopathy
item.description: Lecture notes on autism and sociopathy.

item.title: XXV Character and Morals
item.description: Lecture notes on character and morals, normative ethical theories, John M. Doris on virtue, and three responses to Doris.

item.title: XXVI Character and Morals
item.description: Lecture notes on character and morals, normative ethical theories, John M. Doris on virtue, and three responses to Doris.
